awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms of Lipid Trafficking between the Endoplasmic Reticulum and the Chloroplast
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit: Compartmentation into organelles is a signature trait of all eukaryotic cells and depends on biological membranes containing glycerolipids. Interorganelle lipid trafficking is essential, because different organelles cooperate in the biosynthesis of lipid precursors required for the assembly of specific subcellular membranes. A prominent example is the formation of the photosynthetic thylakoid membranes in plant chloroplasts. Galactoglycerolipids are the most abundant lipid components of these membranes and their biosynthesis serves as a paradigm for the study of lipid transfer from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) to the chloroplast. Long-term, the genetic and biochemical analysis of this process is expected to provide a mechanistic 
understanding of interorganelle lipid trafficking phenomena in plants and other organisms. A collection of 25 Arabidopsis mutants is hypothesized to be affected in different aspects of ER-toplastid lipid trafficking. Common to these mutants is a complex, but robust lipid phenotype, the accumulation of oligogalactoglycerolipids giving rise to the trigalactosyldiacylglycerol (tgd) mutant designation. Of the four TGD loci identified at this time, TGD1, TGD2, and TGD3 encode the permease, the substrate-binding protein, and the ATPase subunits of a putative ABC transporter complex in the inner chloroplast envelope membrane. Several lines of indirect evidence suggest that the TGD123 complex mediates the transfer of phosphatidic acid from the outer envelope to the inside of the inner envelope membrane, where it is processed into the diacylglycerol precursor for galactoglycerolipid biosynthesis. The recently identified TGD4 locus encodes a novel cytosolic non-intrinsic membrane protein, which appears to be associated with the ER. It is hypothesized that the TGD4 protein is directly involved in the transfer of lipid precursors from the ER to the outer chloroplast envelope, possibly by mediating the formation of direct contact zones between these two membranes. Three specific aims will be pursued: 

1.The biochemical and molecular function of the TGD4 protein will be determined. 2. Uncharacterized tgd loci present in the mutant collection will be mapped and characterized largely by undergraduate students. 3. The working hypothesis for the existence and function of the proposed TGD123 phosphatidic acid transport complex will be tested. 

Broader Impacts: Aside from the scientific impacts mentioned, appropriate training opportunities will be provided for graduate and undergraduate students, as well as postdoctoral researchers. The continuing mapping of tgd loci under aim 2 involves undergraduate students supervised by senior researchers. Genetic mapping in Arabidopsis is based on mature technology and established procedures. However, it is intellectually challenging and enables the training of novices in fundamental lab skills. The procedures can be divided into small tasks fitting with a student's class schedule. Students participate in weekly lab meetings and give annual presentations on their work at regional meetings and during on-campus events. Undergraduate students are regularly included as coauthors on publications. In addition, the project will participate in a summer training program in Plant Genomics that was recently implemented at MSU (www.plantgenomics.msu.edu).

por.por_cntn:
Broader Impact: All biological membranes define boundaries of cells and organelles, but can also have more specialized functions. One prominent example is the photosynthetic thylakoid membrane inside plant chloroplasts, which catalyzes the conversion of sunlight into chemical energy. Like many other subcellular membranes, the thylakoids are incapable of generating their own lipids, the building blocks of membranes. Thylakoid lipids are assembled at the inner and outer envelope membranes of the chloroplast and at the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). Thus, thylakoid lipid precursors have to be imported from the ER, exchanged between the two chloroplast envelope membranes, and delivered to the thylakoids. This work greatly contributed to our long term goal to understand the mechanisms of lipid transfer from the ER and through the chloroplast envelope membranes. This process is essential for the assembly of the photosynthetic membrane. Proper assembly of a functional photosynthetic membrane gives existence to all photoautotrophic organisms including plants, and indirectly to most heterotrophic organisms that depend on food and atmospheric oxygen supplied by photosynthetic organisms at the bottom of the food chain. Thus, it is appropriate to conclude that lipid import into chloroplasts is as important to life on earth as the assembly of photosynthetic complexes.

 Intellectual Merit: The reported findings are building on our discovery and initial analysis of the first proteins involved in chloroplast lipid import. The isolation of Arabidopsis mutants deficient in ER-derived lipids in the chloroplast led to the identification of four proteins implicated in the import of lipid precursors from the ER. Their designation derives from the diagnostic but secondary phenotype of the respective tgd mutants, which accumulate the oligogalactolipid TriGalactosyl-Diacylglycerol due to the activation of a galactolipid remodeling enzyme.

The detailed analysis of the TGD1,2,3,4 proteins of the model plant Arabidopsis conducted during the course of this work has provided first clues to their in vitro activities and their organization into complexes and led to a refined hypothesis of their function. As a result of the work conducted we now propose that the TGD proteins form a “lipid conduit” between the ER and the inner envelope. A catalytic sequence starting with polar lipid extraction from the ER and its transfer through the involved TGD complexes --the lipid conduit-- to the inner leaflet of the inner envelope membrane is proposed, which is energetically driven by the hydrolysis of ATP.

Supporting evidence for the lipid conduit model gathered during the course of this work can be summarized as follows: TGD1 is the permease component of an ATP Binding Cassette (ABC) transporter in the inner envelope membrane. The ATPase component of this transporter is TGD3, which is located on the stroma side of the inner envelope membrane where photosynthetic ATP is readily available. TGD2 is a phosphatidic acid (PtdOH) binding protein. It is anchored with a membrane-spanning domain in the inner envelope membrane facing the intermembrane space with its C-terminal domain. Our in vitro functional analysis of the soluble C-terminal portion of TGD2 indicates that it binds PtdOH, and disrupts and fuses adjacent membrane. Thus, TGD2 has the correct location and properties to interact with the outer envelope membrane while being anchored in the inner envelope membrane. Recently, we were able to isolate a stable TGD1,2,3 containing complex from Arabidopsis and pea chloroplasts of >500 kDa. A ratio of 2:2:8 for the TGD1, 3, and 2 proteins, respectively, is consistent with the complex size as well as molecular masses and mass spectral counts observed for the respective components.

The TGD4 protein is predicted to have a C-terminal β-barrel domain and has N-terminal PtdOH binding domains. Our recent analysis of native TGD4 by fractionation and immunodetection of TGD4 with a highly purified and specific TGD4 antibody suggests that the bulk of TGD4 is associated with the outer chloroplast envelope. TGD4 forms its own complex of ~150 kDa possibly representing three TGD4 subunits.

 Training and Outreach: Training opportunities were provided for postdoctoral researchers C. Xu (now Assistant Research Scientist at Brookhaven National Laboratory), J. Gao (now Washington State University) and R. Roston; graduate students B. Lu (now postdoc at University of Michigan) and Z. Wang; undergraduate students A. Manoli, A. Cornish (now graduate student at MSU), A. Cooper, J. Zhao, K. Windak, and N. Anderson. The students, postdocs, and PI regularly gave seminars or presented posters on the research findings at national and international meetings and at other research institutions including some at small undergraduate colleges (e.g. Hope College, MI, Feb 2008). During the Fall of 2010, the PI taught a five hour high school teacher training workshop at MSU as part of the “Frontiers in Science Program”. Similarly, one of the postdocs in the lab participated in an MSU 4-H Science Discovery Camp at MSU. An educational video on Arabidopsis lipid analysis was produced and published.
